item.title: Measurement
item.description: This post was inspired by reading Krantz, D. H., Luce, R. D., Suppes, P., & Tversky, A. (1971). Foundations of measurement: AddÄ±tive and polynomial. Representations, 1. The authors first define a relational structure $ \left( A, \succsim, \circ \right)$ and argue that the point of measurement is to find an homomorphism between it and $\left( \mathbb{R}, \geq, + \right)$. Translated, there must exist a function $m : A \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ such that for all $x, y \in A$ it holds that $x \succsim y \iff m \left(x \right) \geq m \left( y \right)$, i.
